sourcing.instructions: Hg: Obtain from chemical supply companies; La: Buy from rare earth metal suppliers; O: Source from chemical retailers (as oxygen gas); Sn: Acquire from electronic component suppliers.
steps: Hg: Obtain from chemical supply companies; La: Buy from rare earth metal suppliers; O: Source from chemical retailers (as oxygen gas); Sn: Acquire from electronic component suppliers.

1. Measure out 10.5 g of mercury (Hg) using a precision scale. 2. Measure 13.4 g of lanthanum (La) and place it in a clean mixing container. 3. Measure 5.6 g of oxygen (O) and prepare for the reaction. 4. Measure 1.5 g of tin (Sn) and set aside. 5. In a fume hood, carefully combine Hg, La, and Sn in the mixing container and ensure thorough mixing. 6. Gradually introduce O while stirring to ensure uniform distribution. 7. Mix until a homogenous paste is formed.
preparation.raw_text: 1. Measure out 10.5 g of mercury (Hg) using a precision scale. 2. Measure 13.4 g of lanthanum (La) and place it in a clean mixing container. 3. Measure 5.6 g of oxygen (O) and prepare for the reaction. 4. Measure 1.5 g of tin (Sn) and set aside. 5. In a fume hood, carefully combine Hg, La, and Sn in the mixing container and ensure thorough mixing. 6. Gradually introduce O while stirring to ensure uniform distribution. 7. Mix until a homogenous paste is formed.

steps: 1. Transfer the mixture into a crucible. 2. Heat in a controlled furnace to 600°C. 3. Maintain this temperature for 4 hours to ensure complete reaction and formation of the compound.
heating.raw_text: 1. Transfer the mixture into a crucible. 2. Heat in a controlled furnace to 600°C. 3. Maintain this temperature for 4 hours to ensure complete reaction and formation of the compound.

steps: 1. After the heating duration, turn off the furnace. 2. Allow the crucible to cool down gradually to room temperature, taking approximately 2 hours. 3. Do not open the furnace door during cooling to avoid rapid temperature changes.
cooling.raw_text: 1. After the heating duration, turn off the furnace. 2. Allow the crucible to cool down gradually to room temperature, taking approximately 2 hours. 3. Do not open the furnace door during cooling to avoid rapid temperature changes.

steps: 1. Once cooled, carefully remove the solid sample from the crucible using appropriate tools. 2. Inspect the sample for any surface imperfections. 3. Sand the edges and surfaces lightly to achieve a smooth finish. 4. Optionally, seal the surface with an appropriate resin to enhance durability.
